title-group.article-title: Neck Abscess due to Goose Feathers Leaked From a Down Comforter
title-group.subtitle: Case Report, Review of Literature, and Recommendations for Parents

abstract.p: We present a 10-month-old baby girl who developed a neck abscess from the penetration of neck skin by 2 goose feathers that leaked from a down comforter. We review the risks of down and feather bedding and discuss consumer recommendations for parents and pediatricians.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Differences in bedding liners, pillow-type, and feather leakage can have important health effects, especially among infants. Here we present an under-recognized potential hazard of leaked feathers from down-bedding products.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 10-month-old girl was brought to her pediatrician for evaluation of chills, right ear pain, and low-grade fever. On exam, the patient had a right serous middle ear effusion and tender punctate spot of erythema at the right neck. The patient was prescribed a course of oral antibiotics. She presented to the emergency department several days later with an enlarging, painful right neck mass and was admitted for intravenous clindamycin and ceftriaxone antibiotics. Pediatric otolaryngology consultation was arranged for further evaluation. On physical exam, the patient had a 6.5 cm × 2.0 cm right neck mass located just below the angle of the mandible in the mid-cervical region with erythema of the overlying skin (Figure 1). The mass was fluctuant, warm to touch, and tender to palpation. The patient was taken to the operating room for incision and drainage of this apparent neck abscess. A significant amount of pus was drained. On further dissection of the abscess cavity, 2 foreign bodies (2 small goose feathers, Figure 2) were found and removed. The abscess culture revealed Enterococcus species. The infant recovered uneventfully on a 7-day regimen of oral augmentin antibiotics.

sec.p: The parents described periodically finding loose goose feathers emanating from outside of their baby’s comforter and reported removing the feathers as they noticed them.

sec.title: Review of Literature
sec.p: Medline search revealed 71 articles relating to feather bedding and 22 articles relating to feather pillows. Titles were reviewed and a subset of relevant abstracts and full-text articles were reviewed. Overall, the articles found predominantly explored allergy and allergy-related symptoms and their association, or disassociation, with feather bedding use; there were no previous reports in the English medical literature of infection due to traumatic penetration of neck skin by goose feathers.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We present an infant with a neck infection due to the accidental and unwitnessed penetration of neck skin by 2 feathers that leaked from a down comforter. The sharp feather quills infiltrated her skin and resulted in a localized nidus of infection with bacterial translocation under the superficial skin and thin subcutaneous tissue. This case draws attention to the importance of liner quality in bedding products used by infants.

Feather filled bedding products have also been shown to cause infections through fungal contamination. Evans et al. reported a rare case of a 30-year-old chicken feather pillow that had been infected by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, resulting in the development of Histoplasmosis in an infant who had slept with the pillow.1 Although it is rare for this specific fungal-type to infect pillows, it is important to keep in mind that both synthetic and feather pillows are contaminated by a substantial load of fungus; Aspergillus fumigatus (a well recognized allergenic fungus) has been shown to predominate in synthetic pillows and Aureobasidum pullulans (a non-allergenic fungus)has been shown to predominate in feather pillows.2 Fungal contamination has resulted in airway inflammation, and has been speculated to damage the airways or to serve as a constant source for antigenic exposure if fungal colonization and germination in the airways occurs.2

Historically, physicians discouraged feather bedding use because of reports of bird-related forms of extrinsic allergic alveolitis subsequent to feather-filled product contact. These cases involved bronchoalveolar inflammation, reduced lung diffusion capacity, fever, chills, and cough on avian antigen exposure.3,4 In these cases, feather avoidance was curative, and the asthma-affected were often cautioned against feather-filled bedding.3,4 However, those allergic outbreaks might have been from house dust mite (HDM) sensitivity, since HDMs thrive in raw feathers, but today, down-bedding manufacturers remove HDMs by washing and hot drying them making allergy to feather-filled bedding less common.5

Asthmatic patients may experience more adverse effects when sleeping with synthetic bedding, compared with feather bedding, because synthetic products tend to have higher levels of HDM and pet allergens, volatile organic compounds, and pro-inflammatory β-(1,3)-glucans.6,7 Sleeping with synthetic bedding is also a risk factor for rhinitis and severe childhood asthma.8,9 Feather-filled bedding use results in decreased risk for developing asthma, HDM sensitization, and bronchial obstruction in children, and has demonstrated symptom improvement for the eczema and allergic rhinitis affected.5,10

Differences in health outcomes for bedding types might result from differences in calendarization levels in bedding covers. Feather-filled products are often covered with tighter weaving, compared with synthetic-filled products, which might reduce allergen exposure by blocking the entrance and exit of fungal species, HDM and pet allergens, super-antigens, and irritants in bed.2,6,11 Similarly, intervention with an “allergen-impermeable” bed covering significantly decreases bedding dust and eczema severity.12 However, allergen -impermeable coverings would be best implemented into a multisystem allergen-avoidance program since allergens can accumulate on other local reservoirs, since they are blocked from inside the mattress.13

In summary, down-bedding can be hazardous for infants due to the possibility of feather leaking. This risk can be prevented by buying a product that is more “down proof” and/or has an occlusive encasing. Parents and pediatricians should be aware of the risks associated with down-bedding. Consumers can reduce the risk of feather leaking and prevent allergy symptoms by using down-products with the following characteristics: (a) a high proportion of down-filling compared with feather-filling and (b) a bedding cover that is allergen impermeable densely woven.
